title: DOM Based Reflected Cross Site Scripting
content:
Summary:
I hope you're doing well. I stumbled upon one of your assets. Upon further inspection I realized that the asset was running an outdated version of Swagger.
The outdated version of Swagger is well-known for Cross-Site Scripting vulnerabilities so I went ahead and attempted to test it in https://notification-server-v2.sz-my.mtn.com/. Turns out, it's vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting. To reproduce it, please follow the steps of reproduction. I have not assessed the full impact of this vulnerability but it is highly probable that a malicious actor could exploit to takeover accounts of applications hosted under *.mtn.com. I hope this gets patched soon. If there's some additional information that you need from my side, please let me know. Thank you.

vuln_description: The vulnerability is a DOM-based reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in an outdated version of Swagger used by the notification server. By injecting a malicious script via the 'configUrl' parameter, an attacker can execute arbitrary JavaScript in the context of the victim's browser session.
reason: The attack is straightforward, involving only a single parameter manipulation in the URL. The vulnerability is well-documented for the outdated Swagger version, making it easy to discover and exploit without complex interactions or state manipulations.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves DOM-based reflected XSS in an outdated Swagger UI, which is a client-side issue. The proposed methodologies focus on server-side authentication and authorization issues (IDOR and AuthN/AuthZ bypass) by manipulating user sessions and resource IDs. Since XSS does not involve these server-side authorization checks, the methodology would not detect this vulnerability.
